item.description:
The O‚ÄôReilly programming newsletter just linked to an article about vim versus emacs. It‚Äôs 2018 ‚Äì just say no to nerd shibboleths.

Atom, Sublime Text and VS Code are all accessible to new users, just as productive, and their editing shortcuts work elsewhere in the OS.

Lesson also not learned in 2018. üìö

The Sciences of the Artificial, Herbert Simon.

What use is a belief if you don‚Äôt operationalize it? Either you change your behavior, or the belief is decoration. As a man and a feminist, step one is to develop the procedure ‚Äúnotice dishes, then wash dishes‚Äù.

item.title: Excellence on Uncool Hardware
item.description:
What Nick Heer dubs ‚ÄúThe Bullshit Web‚Äù is already intolerable on carefullly-managed, developer class hardware. The web is barely functional on low-end machines. Try going to Staples and browsing the Dell website on a $300 laptop ‚Äì it‚Äôs eye-opening.

Some machines in that price class are better and the savvy consumer can do alright with the Wirecutter‚Äôs help. But it‚Äôs not uncommon for manufacturer‚Äôs to skimp on CPU and RAM in favor of irrelevant bells and whistles and I wouldn‚Äôt trust the sales staff at a big box retailer to steer a shopper in that right direction.

The financial and technical bottleneck to having a good experience online is so much worse than you think. At least the websites for government agencies are stuck in fifteen-year old designs that will function well on cheap hardware.

If you are a software developer and want your work to be an empowering and democratizing force, you need to be excellent on uncool hardware.
I think it‚Äôs time, on this visit to my parents house, to admit that reading these Reader‚Äôs Digest summaries in the bathroom as a teenager is probably my biggest intellectual influence.
I‚Äôm seeing commercials and TV new for the first time in months. Every time it‚Äôs a shock how awful it is.
I finished Martha Nussbaum‚Äôs The Therapy of Desire yesterday, which was an extraordinarily clear exposition of Aristotelian, Epicurean, Skeptical, and Stoic ethics. What a writer!

item.title: What's on your patronage list?
item.description:
After reading Tim Carmody on patronage last year, I am increasingly signing up to support things I love financially. Right now:

  • Aeon.co
  • MetaFilter
  • The Partially-Examined Life
  • Do By Friday

Two articles I read today have me thinking about how a 9-5 job disrupts valuable human rhythms:

  • No Tech Magazine describes tending to fermentation projects in the kitchen as you pass through.
  • The New York Times covers timing meals with your circadian rhythm, in an 8-10 hours window.

My dentist moved next door to my favorite local book store, so of course I dropped in and bought books two and three of the Binti series. I started in on Binti: Home more or less immediately.

üìö

Just nuked my Amazon wishlist from orbit, after realizing that it represented a decade of reading. Time to take a deep breath and get more deliberate about this.

üìö

I came across @ayjay‚Äôs post ‚Äúin responsibility begin dreams‚Äù, which earned a spot on the cork board by my desk.

Everything has been tried and found wanting, and found difficult and left untried. This is the human condition.

Recommended reading for today: Venkatesh Rao‚Äôs ‚ÄúThe Zeroth Mile‚Äù makes the case for becoming ‚Äúanthropocene literate‚Äù, to open our attention to how our lives are grounded in streams of resources and waste.
I consolidated my unread books on one shelf, per Farnam Street. Most of these were acquired by impulse - now it‚Äôs time to stew on the whole thing and see if I can retcon a theme. üìö
I started the Farnam Street course ‚ÄúThe Art of Reading‚Äù yesterday, which so far seems promising. My favorite part is emailing my homework and getting a personal response. üìö

Just learned that micro.blog can mirror your content to a Git repo. I imagine that‚Äôs going to be a niche feature, but huge props to @manton for including it. One-off data export is the bar I expect, automated mirroring wins the gold medal.
Maybe mechanical keyboard fans just need to work on their typing skills a little?
For your Sunday, set aside 25 minutes and watch/listen to ‚ÄúJust Ancient Loops‚Äù, which is intensely beautiful.

item.title: Tell It To Your Robot Bird Friend
item.description: My son calls our grill his ‚Äúrobot bird friend‚Äù. If I squint, the shelves do resemble wings. Either way, what an awesome phrase.

My Independence Day plans:

Continue reading The Monarchy of Fear, in which Martha Nussbaum examines the damage to our democracy wrought by fear.

Also, a parade, hot dogs, and ice cream.

The WSJ snarked on people who use quantified self to motivate consistent meditation. I wrote up my take on the Beeminder blog:

blog.beeminder.com/meditatio‚Ä¶

I was interviewed for (but not quoted in) a WSJ article about people who strive to maintain daily meditation streaks. I don‚Äôt fit the narrative of ‚Äúnerds missing the point of meditation‚Äù, so I‚Äôm pleased to have been left out.

I‚Äôm feeling torn between micro.blog and Mastodon as a Twitter alternative. This is a nice, sunny place, but Mastodon feels like it might pick up more of the surreal humor culture of Twitter.

Between Slack, Discourse, Micro.blog, and Mastodon, my social networks are fragmenting.

I initially found tweetstorms irritating as hell, but I‚Äôm now 100% on board. The format leads to amazing low-ceremony brain dumps from experts, like Sarah Taber on cattle feed and JIT supply chains:

twitter.com/SarahTabe‚Ä¶
Thank you for ‚ÄúHow to keep going‚Äù, Austin Kleon‚Ä¶ just what I needed this morning.
I‚Äôm making an Electron app to visualize the network structure of my Evernote corpus. It is not as interesting a graph as I had hoped!

Today, I dedicate myself to developing the Excellence of screen doors and plant hangers. I beseech you, Hephaestus, to guide my hands.

(h/t Jo Walton and the Thessaly trilogy)
My favorite part of Instapapering an article from a LinkedIn blog is having the number of recruiter notifications I‚Äôm currently ignoring memorialized in the title.

I love @robinsloan‚Äôs take on the game Fortnite & taking a chance on cooperation in a zero-sum space.

Reminds me of Cory Doctorow‚Äôs ‚ÄúWeaponized Narrative‚Äù: a gesture of cooperation opens a counternarrative to the battle royale.

I suspect that amateur developers have an easier time of building automation on iOS, in AppleScript, and similar, due to not knowing how comparatively bad the toolchain and development environments are. I love Drafts, for example, but the feedback loop when testing is slow.

In Conversational Design, Erika Hall frames software as one venue for a customer to engage in conversation with a company providing them with a service. The software should reflect any context the customer shared with a human representative‚Ä¶ and vice versa.

Spreadsheets and scripting languages are optimized for helping a person interactively make sense of a mess ‚Äì and most of our problems are messes. ‚ÄúReal software‚Äù should grow out of the knowledge gained by schlepping through a mess.
A day out in the sun, then putting my kid to bed‚Ä¶ by the time 8 PM rolls around, I‚Äôm completely exhausted. This is why I wake up early for me time.

I love Low-Tech Magazine for looking at technologies not in terms of efficiency, but in terms of the services the technologies provide. ‚ÄúEfficient‚Äù implies only one direction for progress, but there are also gains in giving up net-harmful services.

What I‚Äôve learned today: the price elasticity of demand is a measure of how demand for a good changes in response to changes in its price. A Veblen good is one where demand goes up as the price increases, because signalling that you can afford it is the point.

I reserved a username with the Eco currency today. After reading the design proposal, it seems like the first cryptocurrency open to the existing value in institutional trust. It probably looks like a waste of time to purists ‚Äì and that is why I‚Äôm interested.

If I understand Markov chain Monte Carlo methods correctly, they tell us ‚Äì given a plausible model of the world ‚Äì what values of parameters produce the greatest number of histories compatible with what actually happened?

Different communities of practice use different ways of saying similar things. To cultivate better listening, unpack the assumptions behind the words rather than interpreting the words in your pre-existing frame of reference.

An ‚Äúecho chamber‚Äù forms from weaponizing ad hominem attacks, as opposed to the selection bias that leads to filter bubbles. I would love to see Nicky Case‚Äôs simulation of knowledge transmission through crowds extended to model trained distrust and the rebound effects.
Ordered my first issue of Mortise & Tenon, not because I am a carpenter (I am not), but just for love of gorgeous material things going against the grain of production in 2018.

Software developers learn to navigate by aesthetics as a proxy for quality, but if we optimize for aesthetics too early, we kill our throughput of learning. Embrace ugly scaffolding where it de-risks experimentation.

In person, the involuntary body language of peers does at least some of the work (thought not all) of inhibiting racist/sexist language. Online, disapproval has a higher transaction cost. Online communities need explicit codes of conduct for parity.

Sarah Mei addressed how pair programming and dogmatic adherence to agile practices make work challenging for heterogeneous teams. Although her examples touched on race and gender, what she said also applies to introverts.

Like accessibility, feminism is for everyone.

Craig Mod:

I‚Äôve come to think of tools as granters of permission.

This is a great heuristic. When a tool sufficiently lowers transaction costs, you can accelerate a frivolous use until something qualitatively new emerges from abundance.
‚Äúwhen you build a thing [you] must also repair the world around it‚Äù -A Pattern Language
